awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to engage students in meaningful scientific data collection, analysis, visualization, modeling, and interpretation. It targets grades 9-12 science instruction. The proposed research poses the question "How do learners conceive of and interact with empirical data, particularly when it has a hierarchical structure in which parameters and results are at one level and raw data at another?" As working with data becomes an integral part of students' learning across STEM curricula, understanding how students conceive of data grows ever more important. This is particularly timely as science becomes more and more data driven.

The team will develop and test a Common Online Data Analysis Platform (CODAP). STEM curriculum development has moved online, but development of tools for students to engage in data analysis has yet to follow suit. As a result, online curriculum development projects are often forced to develop their own data analysis tools, settle for desktop tools, or do without. In a collaboration with NSF-funded projects at the Concord Consortium, Educational Development Center, and University of Minnesota, the project team is developing an online, open source data analysis platform that can be used not only by these three projects, but subsequently by others.
 
The proposed research breaks new ground both in questions to be investigated and in methodology. The investigations build on prior research on students' understanding of data representation, measures of center and spread, and data modeling to look more closely at students' understanding of data structures especially as they appear in real scientific situations.  Collaborative design based on three disparate STEM projects will yield a flexible data analysis environment that can be adopted by additional projects in subsequent years. Such a design process increases the likelihood that CODAP will be more than a stand-alone tool, and can be meaningfully integrated into online curricula. CODAP's overarching goal is to improve the preparation of students to fully participate in an increasingly data-driven society. It proposes to do so by improving a critical piece of infrastructure: namely, access to classroom-friendly data analysis tools by curriculum developers who wish to integrate student engagement with data into content learning.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Data are everywhere. No significant problem, be it global warming or how to market a new gadget, can be addressed without the involvement of people who know how to work with data. But such people, now and in the foreseeable future, are in critically short supply. This project addresses the pressing need for more meaningful engagement with data by students and teachers from grade 4 through the first two years of college so that they will acquire data skills early, use them often, and be prepared to build on their understanding of data throughout their lives.

The CODAP project resulted in:

  1. Free, open source, browser-based, data exploration software that can be used as a standalone tool by students and teachers or as a platform on which STEM curriculum projects can build.

  2. Pioneering data science education research leading to important insights in how students make sense of hierarchical data structures.

  3. Formation of a vibrant community of educators interested in data science education by hosting a two-day “Data Science Education Technology” conference, by holding an ongoing series of webinars on data science education, and by organizing data science education meetups at various conferences.

The CODAP Software

As of the end of this project (August, 2017) CODAP was already being used as a data exploration learning environment by many thousands of students as part of their STEM studies. It is free, requires no installation or login, and comes with sample data documents and a comprehensive help system. Figure 1 shows one of the sample documents with graphs and a table. Dynamic selection, so that clicking on points or table rows selects corresponding cases in all other representations proves to be a powerful tool for finding patterns in data.

Although designed for use for students as early as grade 4, CODAP provides a powerful and flexible set of capabilities that students can learn to make use through repeated encounters over many grades and subject areas. Some of these capabilities are listed here:

  • Drag and drop of data into graphs and maps

  • Dynamic linked selection

  • Categorical and numeric plots

  • Maps that handle point or area data (See Figures 3 and 4)

  • The ability to define attributes with formulas

  • Sliders for use as parameters and for animation

  • “Plugins” embedded in CODAP can produce data and freely communicate with CODAP (See Figure 5)

  • CODAP documents can easily be shared with others or embedded in web pages

Data Science Education Research

Research into how learners conceive of data and how they approach exploration, visualization, and analysis of data benefits the entire education community including students, teachers, and designers of curricula and educational software. The CODAP project conducted research through interviews of middle school students, looking to discover ways in which students interact with data structured hierarchically. This research is described in a paper, “Students Making Sense of Multilevel Data,” submitted for publication in the online journal Technology Innovations in Statistics Education.

Building a Data Science Education Community

The project has formed a vibrant community around both the CODAP software and the movement to bring about data science education, especially at the school level. The fifteen collaborating projects listed in Figure 2 form the core of the community that is supporting the ongoing development of CODAP as a platform for continuing curriculum and software development.

In February, 2017 the CODAP project sponsored a two-day conference in Berkeley, California attended by approximately 100 people. Figure 6 shows the front page of the archived web site for the conference.

The CODAP project initiated a series of data science education webinars beginning with three limited-invitation webinars before the conference and, so far, seven open-invitation webinars after the conference with three more planned. Videos of these webinars form a valuable resource of ideas, questions, and discussions.

Concord Consortium has taken on the mission of continuing to promote data science education at the school level.

Selected Publications

  • Finzer, William and Damelin, Dan. Building the CODAP Community @Concord Fall 2015.

  • Finzer, William, and Daniel Damelin. "Co-Design of the Common Online Data Analysis Platform (CODAP) for Cross-disciplinary Use at Grades 6–14." To be published in Proceedings of the Tenth International Conference on Teaching Statistics. Voorburg: International Statistics Institute, 2018.

  • Halder, L.C., Wong, N., Heller, J.I. (2016). Students Making Sense of Multi-level Data. Annual meeting of American Educational Research Association, 2016. Washington, DC.

  • Konold, Cliff, William Finzer, and Kosoom Kreetong. "Modeling As a Core Component of Structuring Data." Statistics Education Research Journal 16, no. 2 (2017): 191-212

  • Pallant, Amy, Lee, Hee-Sun, and Kimball, Nathan. Analytics and Student Learning: An Example from InquirySpace, @Concord Spring 2015

Links to Resources

CODAP: www.codap.concord.org

Sample CODAP documents: https://concord-consortium.github.io/codap-data/

CODAP data interactive plugins: https://concord-consortium.github.io/codap-data-interactives/

Data Science Education Webinars: https://concord.org/meetup/

 

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2018
Modified by: William F Finzer

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1. A simple CODAP example document containing data for 27 mammals. It displays a case table, 3 graphs, and a guide. The Cheetah shows as selected in all representations.
    Concord Consortium
    Public Domain
    William F Finzer
    CODAP Mammals Example Document
  • Figure 2: Chart of 15 project collaborations established and carried out during the CODAP funding period. The first 3 collaborations were funded by CODAP and the remainder either provided their own funding or were undertaken without funding.
    Concord Consortium
    Public Domain
    William F Finzer
    CODAP Visualization of Collaborating Projects
  • Figure 3: CODAP combines mapping capabilities with graphing so that geographic relationships can be explored. Notice the strikingly low alcohol use across North Africa and South Asia. Also, Russia stands out as high consumer of alcohol.
    Concord Consortium
    Public Domain
    William F Finzer
    CODAP Map Linked with Graphics
  • Figure 4: A tracking device attached to Birgit the tortoise reveals nearly a year?s worth of detailed movement data. She climbed high up on the volcano wall at three different times.
    Concord Consortium
    Public Domain
    William F Finzer
    Tracking a Giant Tortoise in the Galapagos
  • Figure 5: The simulation plugin produces data under student control. The measurements are grouped hierarchically into runs. A formula computes the final velocity.
    Concord Consortium
    Public Domain
    William F Finzer
    Parachute Simulation Embedded in CODAP
  • Figure 6: This conference was attended by approximately 100 educators from all over the world.
    Concord Consortium
    Public Domain
    William F Finzer
    The website for the Data Science Education Technology (DSET) Conference
